questions.question: Why are preschool age children at a higher risk for a foodborne illness?

They have not yet built up a strong immune system
They are more likely to suffer allergic reactions
They are more susceptible to choking hazards

Their immune systems can be compromised
The medications will upset their stomach

A foodborne illness is

a disease transmitted to people through food

choices: person to person, from people to food and from people to food contact surfaces

questions.question: After which activity must food handlers wash their hands?
What should food handlers do after prepping food and before using the restroom?
Which piece of jewelry can be worn on a food handlers hand or arm?
When should hand antiseptics be used?
choices: When gloves are not being used

questions.question: When should food handlers who wear gloves wash their hands?
choices: Before going home for the day

questions.question: A cook wore single use gloves while forming raw ground beef into patties. The cook continued to wear the gloves while slicing hamburger buns. What mistake was made?
choices: The cook did not wear reusable gloves while handling the raw ground beef and the hamburger buns.
The cook did not clean and sanitize the gloves before handling the hamburger buns.
The cook did not wash, rinse and sanitize his/her gloves before slicing the hamburger buns.
The cook did not wash his/her hands and put on new gloves before slicing the hamburger buns.

questions.question: A food handler has been diagnosed with an illness from Shigella spp. What should the manager tell the food handler to do?
choices: Stay home until a doctor approves him to return to work.
Wear gloves while handling all foods.
Work only in a non-food handling position.
Be put on as a greeter.

questions.question: A food handler prepares and delivers meals to elderly individuals receiving cancer care services at home. What symptoms require this food handler to stay home from work?

choices: When sitting in a break area

questions.question: What should a manager of a hospital cafeteria do if a cook calls in with a headache, nausea and diarrhea?
choices: Tell the cook to stay away from work and see a doctor.
Tell the cook to come in for a couple of hours to only clean the floor and then go home.
Tell the cook to rest for a couple of hours and come to work if he no longer has any symptoms.
Tell the cook to go to the doctor and then immediately come to work with a note.

questions.question: All of the following are bad personal habits that can contaminate food except:
choices: An employee that touches his hair often
An employee who picks her teeth
An employee who puts his hands in his pockets and under his arms often

questions.question: Food could be easily contaminated by an employee who:

choices: After shaking hands with a customer and returning to handle food

add more heat to kill any pathogens in the soup
immediately freeze the soup and re-heat it at a later date
immediately serve the soup as samples, as long as customers are not charged for it

questions.question: If a thermometer is dropped or bumped, it must be
choices: calibrated, washed, rinsed, sanitized and air-dried

have a pencil and paper ready

choices: Unlimited time as long as he cools it to 41°F before serving it

Identify, document, and use the correct methods for receiving foods

choices: developing a HACCP plan for all food service establishments

choices: wash hands before returning to work

questions.question: Too strong sanitizing solution left on a plate is an example of what type of contamination?
